security: Revealing that the CIA conducted a search for unaccounted payments to Howard Hunt, including accessing his bank records and questioning accounting procedures, could expose internal financial and operational practices. Specifically, the memo details opening a special bank account for Hunt at Chase Manhattan Bank and notes an unusual $1,600 write-off approved by Desmond Fitzgerald without further accounting. Sharing this could compromise sensitive operational methods and relationships with banking institutions. Quoting directly, "It was an expenditure of $1,600 for a sensitive operation which was approved for write-off by Mr. Desmond Fitzgerald on 1 June 1966 without further accounting."
summary: The Director of Finance reports to the Inspector General on a search for unaccounted payments to Howard Hunt, finding no large unrecorded payments but noting unusual financial procedures.
summary_one_paragraph: On February 27, 1974, Thomas B. Yale, the Director of Finance, sent a memorandum to the Inspector General detailing a search for unaccounted payments to Howard Hunt, prompted by a request from the Deputy Director for Management and Services. The search covered expense runs, station accountings (Madrid, JMWAVE, FR/Washington), and travel claims but found no undocumented $30,000 payment. A bank account was opened at Chase Manhattan Bank for Hunt for non-salary payments, all of which were accounted for, although an unusual $1,600 expenditure for a sensitive operation was written off without detailed accounting by Desmond Fitzgerald. The memo suggests questioning Mr. Karamessines and potentially requesting a full transcript of Hunt's Chase Manhattan account to uncover any unaccounted operational expenditures.
title: Howard Hunt
